item.description:
How often do you get to give a talk with the word “Flotilla” in the title?

Maybe some day I'll be able to share the recording (it is not public, at the moment). This is a revision / revisitation of what was covered at Oracle CodeOne.

item.title: SpringOne 2019: Monsters and Metrics
item.description:
Two things collided in my brain this year ahead of SpringOne: Preparing a new talk from scratch covering the Micrometer (and the related Spring implementation), and learning everything I needed to know to be a Dungeon Master for my 10-year-old son and his friends.

Thanks to a brilliant suggestion from a friend, these two things collided in the talk, too. Which lightened the mental load (or at least reduced the amount of full stack swapping going on).

Github repository: ebullient/monster-combat with Spring Boot 2, WebFlux, and Micrometer

item.title: CodeOne 2019: Overcoming Obstacles: Streamline Your Move to the Cloud
item.description:
JavaOne is gone, CodeOne is here, and IBM attended to represent a new collection of open source projects attempting to aid companies adopt cloud native development.

Edit: Not all of the tech we brought to CodeOne in 2019 lived for very long, but some of it did address real issues, and I imagine we'll see it creep back in via other methods.

In an interview with Luke Shantz, I described what role I felt Appsody played in the Cloud-native development game, including how it could make developer's lives easier.

item.title: Code @ IBM Think 2019: Cloud-Native Security for Java
item.description: Billy and I put together a tidy little talk about Cloud-Native Security for Java applications to give at “Code @ Think” during the annual IBM Think Conference.

item.title: CF Summit 2018: Cloud Native and the Java Ecosystem
item.description:
I was the lead for the Java track for CF Summit 2018. We had a great slate of speakers.

I was able to make attempt number two for the evolution of Cloud Native and the Java ecosystem.

The Java Ecosystem Collision: What is the Future of Cloud Native? - Erin Schnabel, IBM

item.title: Index 2018: What is a Cloud Native application, anyway?
item.description:
I gave a few talks at Index Developer Conference in San Francisco:

  1. A Workshop! Game-On Text Adventure re-presented in lab form, with some lessons learned along the way.

  2. Testing Cloud Native Applications

  3. What is a Cloud Native Application, anyway? My first attempt at talking about what is going on with Cloud Native applications these days.

I did have a lovely interview with Kevin Allen beforehand:

item.title: SpringOne 2017: Lightning talk on the Mainstage
item.description: I will absolutely confess that it was daunting to start with, but that once I was out on the stage, everything was fine. I will also confess to ad nauseum rehearsal. To reciting what I had to cram into two segments (one only 2 minutes long, and the other 2 minutes and 30 seconds) to every inanimate object in my hotel room: lamps, laptops, mirrors, showerheads, and I'm pretty sure my pillow while I was sleeping. I didn't really wrap my head around what I wanted to say until the night before. Things just didn't fall into place before then. But hey, I lived! It was quite the experience. Watch the #SpringOne mainstage lightning talks on Distributed Systems, featuring @cdavisafc, @meaghnk, @midatlantictez, @ebullientworks, and Mathangi Venkatesan. https://t.co/PVxlz1ta5V — VMware Tanzu (@VMwareTanzu) December 13, 2017

item.title: IBM InterConnect 2017: Microservices, Twelve Factors, Security
item.description:
Lots to talk about this year. So many sessions.

  1. Best practices for creating secure microservices
  2. Creating Twelve Factor Applications with Liberty on Bluemix: a Practical Guide
  3. Monolithic Application to Microservice Architecture: How to break down your existing Application
  4. Real-World Microservice Development with IBM WebSphere Liberty: Game On!

There were a few more that I haven't posted the charts for.. phew!

item.description: Kate Stanley and I took Game On Text Adventure to OSCon London! We spoke about our experiences building the game, and Kate created a new room in Java from scratch and showed the game finding the room, and coping as the service recycled in response to updates.
